urn:contentItem:5TTB-Y0F1-JCBJ-K4R9-00000-00Tech Policy and the Midterm Elections.(Report)2018-10-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:36ZLexisNexisPg. 3CTech Policy and the Midterm Elections.(Report)Layton, Roslyn

Tech policy is the set of norms, rules, regulations, and institutions that govern technology industries. More generally, tech policy is a set of principles and actions about technology, the way in which goods and services are produced in an economy. (1) It is a synthesis of the official strategic efforts to promote specific sectors of the economy through scientific and industrial policy and broader economic and social policy.

The intellectual origins of tech policy include Friedrich List's argument for national support of "infant industries" (2) and Alexander Hamilton's Report on the Subject of Manufactures in 1791, which advocated for modernizing the American economy to break economic dependency on slavery in the South and supersede England in manufacturing. (3) Economist Thorstein Veblen is credited with introducing the German concept of die Technik into American discourse as "technology," meaning more than just the useful arts but the practices and principles in the "state of the industrial arts." (4) He is also credited with coining the term "technological determinism," suggesting that society's technology drives the development of its social structure and cultural values. (5)

Tech policy is also intertwined with military research and development (R&D), though a full discussion is out of scope here. About 1.5 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) goes to R&D efforts focused on "maintaining strategic technological advantages over potential foreign adversaries." (6) Recent examples include Congress' recent reauthorization and budget increase for NASA (7) and the president's announcement to launch a sixth branch of the military, the United States Space Force. (8)

Globally, the tech industry topped $4.5 trillion in revenue in 2017 and is expected to reach $4.8 trillion in 2018. The US is the single-largest tech market in the world and accounts for 31 percent of the global tech market. The US tech economy was $1.6 trillion in 2018, 9.2 percent of GDP. (9) The numbers are even more staggering from an equities perspective; the American tech industry accounts for a quarter of the value of the US stock market, some $34 trillion. (10) There are half a million tech companies in the US, with 34,000 new startups in 2017 alone. (11)

The 2018 Midterm Election

Midterm elections are held two years after the presidential election. All 435 seats in the House of Representatives and 33 seats in the Senate are up for election. Additionally, 34 state governors are up for reelection, including Vermont and New Hampshire, which have only two-year terms for governors. The other 48 governors serve four-year terms. Furthermore, 35 state attorneys general, key legal actors in each state, are also up for election in 2018. In many states, the ballot features elections for state legislatures, local officers, and initiatives. The election will be held November 6.

The midterms are frequently described as a referendum on the president and his party. Since the 1840s, political scientists have observed that the president's party generally loses seats in the midterm election, often called the "presidential penalty." (12) In rare cases, the president's party has netted gains, but the average net loss is 30 seats in the House and four seats in the Senate. (13) Since 1946, the average loss for the president's party when his approval is below 50 percent is 36 seats in the House; when approval is above 50 percent, the average loss is 14 seats. (14)

Instead of a midterm penalty, some researchers note that there could be a midterm reward. Research examining the 2009 midterm found that districts where people evaluated their own lives in more hopeful terms were more likely to reelect incumbents. (15)

To date, the highest loss of party seats in the House of Representatives was 77 seats in 1922, following the election of Republican President Warren Harding. (16) For the Senate, a record 13 seats were flipped in Dwight D. Eisenhower's second term in 1958. (17) In 2010, 63 House seats were flipped to

Republicans. (18)

Presently, there is a razor-thin margin in the Senate with 51 Republicans, 47 Democrats, and two independents who caucus with the Democrats. In the House, Republicans are defending 40 open seats; Democrats, 20. (19) Democrats need to net only 24 seats to win the majority. As of this writing, political experts observe that polls are so close that it is difficult to predict a clear party winner. (20)

Midterm elections tend to have lower turnout than presidential elections. James Campbell's seminal "surge and decline" theory of elections suggests that a surge of interest and information during presidential elections helps one party, while the voters of the disadvantaged party are more likely to stay home. (21) Campbell argues that voter turnout in midterm elections declines as interest returns to normal levels and patterns.

The 2014 midterm marked the lowest voter turnout in 72 years; just 36.4 percent of eligible voters participated. (22) In the 2016 presidential election, 58 percent did. For 2018, one predictive analytic model based on patterns from 2012 to 2016 indicates there will be a drop of 39.8 million voters from the 139 million who voted in 2016, about a 29 percent drop. (23)

However, interest in politics has not declined in 2018, with many new voter registrations and enthusiasm strong in both parties, (24) suggesting that turnout in November could be different. The Pew Research

Center reports that voters are more focused on Congress and the presidency than in past midterms. A record 68 percent of survey respondents say the vote is about the party that controls Congress, and 60 percent say they will vote as a referendum either for or against the president. (25)

Another suggestion for the differences in presidential and midterm years is that there are two electorates: a smaller, older cohort of Americans that leans Republican and reliably votes in both midterms and general elections and a larger, younger cohort that leans Democrat but tends to vote only in the general. (26)

Along that same vein, another theory is that the two electorates are split along the lines of education, those with higher education and those without. Patrick Ruffini of Echelon Insights, a firm specializing in polling, election analytics, and data intelligence, notes, "Usually in midterms there is a turnout drop of with 1) younger voters and 2) non-college educated voters. The dropof with #1 favored the GOP. The dropof with #2 didn't matter, until 2016, and now it could hurt the GOP." (27)

While reviewing the history and statistics of midterm elections is interesting, it tells us little about the role of tech policy in elections. A later section explains some theories of the role of policy in election. But first, a review of the parties' 2016 tech policy platforms is in order.

2016 Tech Policy Platforms

Republicans' and Democrats' respective tech policy positions were described in their 2016 party platforms and in subsequent communications. Both parties' platforms describe the importance and role of technology in employment, education, innovation, partnerships, and infrastructure investment. Both sides also recognize the importance of broadband, 5G, the Internet of Things, intellectual property, outer space, cybersecurity, and online privacy.

The 2016 platforms offered a road map to voters as to how each party would address key tech policy issues. For example, it was clear that Republicans, should they win the presidency, would protect internet freedom, returning to the light-touch bipartisan framework that governed the internet until 2015. They charged that President Barack Obama subjugated the internet at home and abroad "to agents of government," as he "ordered the chair of the supposedly independent Federal Communications Commission to impose upon the internet rules devised in the 1930s for the telephone monopoly" and "unilaterally announced America's abandonment of the international internet by surrendering U.S. control of the root zone of web names and addresses." (28) Democrats declared that they "will oppose any effort by Republicans to roll back the historic net neutrality rules that the Federal Communications Commission enacted last year." (29) The parties' actions since the 2016 election have been consistent with their stated positions.

A review of the official Democratic and Republican policy statements highlights the differences between the parties and how they see the role of technology. In general, Democrats excel at distilling their position into a single sentence--a bumper-sticker credo so to speak. The GOP's explanations are longer but have more concrete and detailed policy positions. Moreover, Republicans frame many of their positions within the context of the Constitution.

For Democrats, science and technology are ends in themselves. Democrats offer a unique policy category to describe science and technology, noting government's specific role to plan the technological economy, educate students, and ensure employment for workers. (30)

Republicans, on the other hand, espouse a foundational set of principles instrumental to all facets of life: freedom, the protection of property, the rule of law, and limited government. They believe this foundation is good for making policy across the board, including tech policy. The GOP also asserts the problems of international internet tyranny and the US government being woefully out of date on technology. (31)

Democrats extoll the social value of technology in everyday life, particularly for community participation. They maintain that tech policy should support women and people of color, promote inclusion, attract and retain talented people from all over the world, and empower people with disabilities. (32)

Republicans celebrate technology's creative and disruptive capacity to challenge legacies and create new markets. They desire that government be a partner with individuals and industries in technological progress, not a "meddlesome monitor." (33) They advocate for a business climate of risk and reward and a fair and open global market that protects data privacy, fosters innovation, and ensures the free flow of data across borders. Republicans want the government to incentivize spectrum access, the sharing economy, and on-demand platforms; modernize federal information technology systems; and recruit skilled professionals to work in government.

A policy that incorporates these many virtuous aspects from both parties would be optimal. Indeed, this has been the case for much of tech policy's success to date. Bipartisan policy incorporates different perspectives and ultimately provides more lasting, sustainable solutions. The differences between the parties become more visible, however, as the discussion moves away from general topics such as technology to more specific policy issues.

For instance, Democrats and Republicans differ in their approach to rural broadband and closing the digital divide. Democrats advocate creating a national infrastructure bank to provide loans and assistance for broadband deployment. (34) Republicans argue that companies would be more likely to deploy networks if regulations were not so onerous. (35)

In the 2016 platform, Democrats pledged to connect every home in America and offer free Wi-Fi. (36) Republicans claimed that the government has spent tens of billions of dollars on broadband subsidies over decades but has failed to realize universal broadband coverage and that rural America has been harmed as a result. They note that from 2014 to 2016, some 10 million Americans canceled their wireline broadband subscriptions, suggesting that consumers are increasingly choosing wireless technologies. They call for a public-private partnership on rural broadband to solve the problem. (37)

While tech policy encompasses a range of issues, the respective party platforms discuss innovation and entrepreneurship, broadband, internet regulation, intellectual property, outer space, cybersecurity, online privacy, and scientific R&D, particularly for the military. Historically, these areas have been largely bipartisan, making them poor midterm campaign issues because there are few points of policy difference.

FTC Accomplishments

The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) plays a key role in tech policy, ensuring competition and consumer protection across the digital ecosystem by policing unfair and deceptive practices. To put the FTC's value into perspective, half its budget is focused on consumer protection. Consider that the FTC processes about 10 times as many robocall complaints, the leading consumer complaint in the digital communications domain, as the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) does. (38) The FTC is clearly a workhorse of consumer protection and complaint adjudication, which is how most consumers know the agency.

Over the years, the FTC's accomplishments have been considerable, but the agency showed particular leadership in the past two years. (39) In 2017 alone, the FTC brought 10 competition cases to court, took action on 25 other competition cases, brought or settled 109 consumer-protection matters, brought

14 data privacy and security cases, and launched a national campaign to identify occupational licensing restrictions that threaten economic liberty. Some of the success can be attributed to FTC commissioners' seven-year terms, which allow stability and continuity, but the record is also remarkable with just two commissioners at the helm during this period.

Enlightened chairmen from both parties have created a constructive work culture, demonstrated by the agency's consistently improving score since 2011 in the "Best Places to Work in the Federal Government" survey. (40) The agency ranks fourth in midsize federal agencies and first in "Employee Engagement and the New Employee Inclusion Quotient in 2017." (41) Notably high scores have also been achieved during political turmoil and a government shutdown. (42)

The FTC's many actions and enforcements prove it is fully capable to regulate the broadband ecosystem with regard to net neutrality, as an interagency memorandum of understanding attests. (43) Importantly, the FTC can secure financial redress for consumers, unlike the FCC. The FTC recently issued its first Office of Claims and Refunds annual report detailing how the FTC's Bureau of Consumer Protection obtained 168 court orders for more than $12.72 billion between July 1, 2016, and June 30, 2017. (44)

This includes settlements with several major companies, (45) including the landmark settlement with Volkswagen over the carmaker's installation of software, which allowed it to cheat emissions regulations. (46) Following FTC action, a federal court ordered Dish Network to pay $280 million for alleged violations of telemarketing rules. (47) The FTC and 32 state attorneys general settled with Lenovo over charges that the company harmed consumers by preloading software on some laptops that compromised security protections to deliver ads to consumers. (48) A settlement with Uber Technologies Inc. required the company to implement a comprehensive privacy and auditing program. (49) The FTC also obtained a $650,000 settlement with the electronic toy manufacturer VTech over allegations of violations of children's online privacy laws. (50) Online tax-preparation service TaxSlayer and "revenge porn" website MyEx were also charged. (51)

The FTC's small business and data security roundtables and business guidance programs help enterprises understand and comply with the law. (52) Internal process reforms in the agency's Bureau of Consumer Protection are underway, (53) as is a long-overdue streamlining of the requirements under the Fur, Textile, and Wool Labeling Rules. (54) Acting Chairwoman Maureen Ohlhausen also launched the Economic Liberty Task Force with national and state partners to reduce onerous occupational licensing requirements, which have deterred many Americans from earning income as hair braiders, flower arrangers, and so on. (55)

The tech press largely ignored this impressive list of accomplishments. One article that did review them concluded that the FTC was not up to task and suggested that it was not doing enough on tech policy, (56) despite the roundtables held on artificial intelligence, blockchain, identity theft, connected cars, and data privacy. (57) This journalistic view may reflect an ideological preference for regulatory agencies to deliver predetermined outcomes even though that falls outside the organization's statutory mandate. FTC leaders are required to fulfill the organization's mission without overstepping the rule of law.

For an agency with a $300 million budget and 1,100 employees, taxpayers get value for money. Even greater efficiency and results can likely be achieved by strengthening the role of economics and empirical analysis in the FTC's work.

Upon taking office, Chairman Joseph Simons announced an inquiry on competition and consumer protection in the 21st century. (58) Areas of focus include:

* Improving communications, information, and media technology networks;

* Identifying and measuring market power and entry barriers;

* Evaluating collusive, exclusionary, or predatory conduct in "platform" businesses;

* Studying the intersection of privacy, big data, and competition;

* Deterring unfair and deceptive conduct in privacy and data security matters;

* Determining the competitive effects of corporate acquisitions and mergers;

* Asssessing the role of intellectual property and competition policy in promoting innovation; and

* Strengthening consumer welfare and the use of algorithmic decision tools, artificial intelligence, and predictive analytics.

Such an inquiry was last undertaken in 1995 under FTC Chairman Robert Pitofsky. (59)

FCC Reauthorization and Accomplishments

Oversight of federal agencies is a basic function of Congress. A subset of oversight, authorization, is a formal certification that the agency fulfills its charter and, in many cases, a legal process for appropriation of funds. After some 30 years and Rep. Greg Walden's (R-OR) promotion as chairman of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, the FCC has finally been reauthorized in a bipartisan fashion. The reauthorization bill was eponymously named the RAY BAUM'S Act to commemorate the veteran staff adviser to the House Energy and Commerce Committee. Among other things, the bill:

* Approves transparency and efficiency reforms at the agency,

* Identifies more licensed and unlicensed spectrum for private-sector use,

* Covers the shortfall promised to relocate broadcasters being displaced following the successful incentive auction,

* Fixes the spectrum auction deposit so the FCC can post funds directly to the US Treasury,

* Directs the FCC to craft a national policy for unlicensed spectrum, and

* Empowers FCC and law enforcement to stop robocalls. (60)

The bill signifies the accomplishment of an essential and long-overdue responsibility of Congress, to evaluate the effectiveness of the FCC.

Digital Empowerment and Closing the Digital Divide. Upon becoming FCC chairman in 2017, Ajit Pai made digital empowerment the goal of his tenure. (61) His Digital Empowerment Agenda is based on four pillars designed to increase access to broadband and unlock digital opportunities for job creation and civic engagement: opportunity zones, mobile broadband in rural areas, regulatory barriers to broadband, and entrepreneurship and innovation. (62) These goals address network availability and affordability, the readiness of users and communities, and relevance of services.

Under Chairman Pai's leadership, the FCC has been busy streamlining rollout requirements to maximize investment in broadband infrastructure in both wireless and wireline networks. (63) The FCC's Mobility Fund has allocated up to $4.53 billion over the next decade to advance 4G/LTE service, primarily in rural areas that would not be served without government support. (64) Additionally, the Connect America Fund Phase II will provide up to $2 billion for rural fixed broadband over the next decade. (65)

Chairman Pai also launched the Broadband Deployment Advisory Committee, a diverse multistakeholder group of five subcommittees targeted to address infrastructure deployment in municipalities and states, competitive access to broadband infrastructure, the regulatory barriers to broadband, and federal siting. (66) Based on this broad-based input, the actions of at least 20 states to make model codes for infrastructure rollout, (67) and existing statute, the FCC has accelerated the transition to next-generation broadband networks. It has modernized rules about utility poles and conduits, revised rules that deter companies from replacing copper with fiber, (68) and established shot clocks to ensure that permissions to deploy infrastructure are reviewed without undue delay. (69) Modernizing infrastructure rules can eliminate 80 percent of the regulatory costs of deploying small cell wireless facilities, cut deployment times in half, and enable more Americans to get next-generation wireless broadband. (70)

US Leadership in 5G and Other Broadband Technologies. Promoting 5G, the fifth-generation mobile wireless standard, is an FCC priority. (71) 5G offers 10-100 times the speed and throughput of current 4G networks, low latency or lagtime to enable technologies such as remote surgery and autonomous vehicles, and a subsitute for fixed line networks. (79)

The FCC's strategy includes allocating spectrum, speeding up infrastructure deployment, and reducing regulatory barriers. (78) The FCC has moved to get more spectrum in the pipeline at high and low frequencies and the mid-band, or the "Goldilocks band," because it has the optimal mix of physical characteristics to cover distance, allow throughput, and penetrate buildings. (72) The 5G spectrum auctions will begin in November. (73)

Additionally, the FCC established new rules on the 3.5 GHz band, (74) which protect national defense radar from interference while allowing flexible wireless broadband use. Notably, cable providers will use the 3.5 GHz (Citizens Broadband Radio Service) to expand internet coverage to unserved areas. (75)

While building networks is important, networks are not ends in themselves. The greater value will be realized when people adopt 5G network services. As such, the application and service development ultimately will matter more, but the actual network deployment is a necessary and urgent prerequisite.

Public Safety. The FCC has advanced important measures for public safety. These include improving the geographic targeting for Wireless Emergency Alerts with requirements to support the use of "clickable" embedded links in alerts so that consumers can easily access additional emergency information. The new "Blue Alert" notifies the public about threats to law enforcement and helps apprehend dangerous suspects. Following the devastating 2017 hurricanes, Ajit Pai traveled to Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands and proposed $954 million to restore and expand networks to the islands. (76)

FCC Commissioner Michael O'Rielly has led the crackdown on 911 fee diversion, exposing states that have illegally siphoned millions of dollars dedicated for 911 emergency service for other purposes. (77) The FCC voted in September 2018 to consolidate its disparate 911 rules (78) and adopt measures to realize Kari's Law, a bipartisan bill signed by President Donald Trump requiring multiline telephone systems to have direct access to 911 calls. The law is named for a Texas woman who was killed by her husband in 2013. The woman's young daughter could not directly access 911 from their motel room phone without first dialing 9. (79)

Process and Regulatory Reform. The FCC took action to eliminate paperwork burdens imposed on regulated companies costing more than $800 million a year, ended the business data services proceedings that had been open for 12 years, streamlined accounting rules that forced providers to maintain two sets of books, and eased reporting burdens for volunteer board members of noncommercial broadcasters. (80) Additionally, following prior administration experience in which meeting materials would not be made available to commissioners in time for voting, the

FCC adopted a transparency rule that requires all its meeting materials to be publicly available three weeks before commission meetings. This rule has proved so effective that it has been proposed as legislation in Congress. (81)

The FCC also proposes to eliminate a report that it no longer uses but that fulfills a 50-year-old requirement for Form 325, which has not been updated in 20 years. The report requires cable operators to collect and submit to the FCC subscriber numbers, equipment information, plant information, frequency and signal distribution information, and programming information. The commission also proposes to liberate the toll-free 800-number market from its earlier first-come, first-serve system to an auction and secondary market model to improve the efficient allocation of toll-free numbers. (82)

Other Tech Policy Developments

President Trump issued a legislative outline for rebuilding the nation's infrastructure by reforming its financing, permitting, and workforce development. (83) His plan prioritizes broadband with incentives for local and private parties to invest in completing and operating rural infrastructure projects. The proposal also suggests improving the flexibility and eligibility for private access bonds, specifically for rural broadband infrastructure.

The president also issued an executive order focused on streamlining and expediting the process and a memorandum supporting towers managed by the Department of the Interior. (84) Moreover, the House Subcommittee on Communications and Technology has had at least two hearings on rural broadband, (85) and seven bills are under review in the House and Senate. (86)

A related issue for broadband infrastructure and general technology investment is the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, the first major tax reform in over 30 years, signed into law on December 22, 2017. (87) Tech companies are the largest American companies and can repatriate significant funds currently held abroad. In the longer term, tax reform could support a higher level of investment, and this is important for the telecom sector, which invests more in the American economy than any other sector. (88)

Separately, the Senate has driven a long-needed reform for the broadband program of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Utilities Service (RUS) to focus federal funding more appropriately to unserved areas, rather than overbuilding existing networks. The legislation directs the RUS to confer with the FCC and the National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) and includes transparency and notice processes. This will help provide the USDA with the latest information about broadband availability and guard against waste, fraud, and abuse. (89)

Major Tech Policy Issues

This section covers the two tech policy issues that have received the most attention during the election cycle: online privacy and the debate between internet freedom and internet regulation.

Online Privacy. In March 2017, Congress restored broadband privacy protections at the FTC. (90) The protections had been in place for decades but were torpedoed by the 2015 FCC Open Internet Order. (91) For some nine months, consumers were left with no broadband protections, so internet service providers (ISPs) voluntarily maintained the FTC privacy standards in the meanwhile. The FCC's new online privacy rules were written and adopted on a party-line basis without establishing a record of harm or showing that the FTC was deficient in policing the area.

While many tech journalists maligned the removal of the FCC's rules and the restoration of the FTC's jurisdiction, (92) the one-sided rules would have created confusion for consumers, applying different regulations on the same service. Whether the rules were applicable depended on the kind of company the FCC could regulate, an arbitrary distinction for consumers. (93) Moreover, the rules created a barrier to entry in the oligopolistic online advertising market. For instance, ISPs were not allowed to offer advertising-supported content on the same conditions as Google and Facebook. (94) While the 2015 FCC declared that ISPs required different and stricter online privacy rules, privacy breaches have mainly occurred on the leading online platforms, not ISPs, and platforms have far more data and insight on users than ISPs do.

During the Obama administration, Silicon Valley companies were celebrated as national treasures. But in 2018, many of these companies have come under scrutiny by both political parties, particularly regarding online privacy. Several tech company CEOs have been called to congressional hearings. A recent poll reports that two-thirds of older Americans (age 53-72), the demographic that reliably votes in all elections, want tech companies to be regulated like big banks, even though respondents overall have some doubts about whether governments can successfully regulate such firms. (95)

In any event, Democrats and Republicans have demonstrated a desire to make consistent online privacy legislation. Draft bipartisan legislation on online privacy has been introduced. (96) Importantly, the bill from Sens. Amy Klobuchar (D-MN) and John Kennedy (R-LA) includes a safe harbor for innovative privacy-enhancing technologies, protecting inventors from being punished for experimentation in proving the privacy design of their systems.

While there is potent media hype about online privacy, Americans overall report nuanced views, describing the value they enjoy from a multitude of connected services and devices. (97) This suggests that an exchange for sharing data is reasonable. To better understand how consumers view the issues, the FTC launched an in-depth investigation into competition and consumer protection in the 21st century, especially the intersection of privacy, big data, and competition and the FTC's remedial authority to deter unfair and deceptive conduct in privacy and data security matters. (98)

Meanwhile, the White House has tasked the NTIA to request comments on a proposed approach to consumer data privacy. (99) The goal is to create principles that protect individuals while giving organizations legal clarity and the flexibility to innovate. It is part of a larger transparent process to modernize US data privacy policy, harmonize international regulation, and support the National Institute of Standards and Technology's development of a voluntary privacy framework based on scientific principles similar to cybersecurity. The principles can inform legislative efforts in Congress.

Regrettably, California has developed its own online privacy legislation, which frustrates a common standard and expectation for all Americans who have enjoyed consuming online services across the 50 states. Its new online privacy law falls into the predictable pseudo-consumer-friendly trap of substituting regulatory compliance over user education and technology innovation.

As can be seen with more than a decade of misguided data-protection regulation from the European Union, including the recent General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), consumers do not report a greater sense of trust online, nor have small- and medium-sized companies significantly entered digital markets. The perverse outcome of heavy-handed rules is that large, established companies are strengthened at the expense of startups. (100)

The scientific research on data protection and privacy suggests that consumer education and privacy-enhancing technologies are essential to creating trust online, (101) but these inputs are noticeably absent in both the GDPR and the California Consumer Privacy Act. Congress can enable the continued prosperity of the information economy by ensuring that consumers can access privacy education to make informed choices, that safe harbors for privacy-enhancing innovation protect the testing and learning for new technologies, and that common standards for competition and consumer protection online are equally guaranteed for all Americans. (102)

Internet Freedom vs. Net Neutrality. Republicans and Democrats differ starkly on internet freedom and net neutrality. Internet freedom recognizes the sovereignty of consumers, not regulators, to decide their preferred parameters of broadband (price, technology, quality, security, durability, mobility, etc.). It was the prevailing bipartisan policy in the US from 1996 to (2015.) Entrepreneurs and investors enjoyed the freedom to experiment and deploy new network technologies. This led to $1.6 trillion in private broadband infrastructure investment, a staggering figure that accounts for a quarter of the world's total outlay for the period. (103)

With internet freedom, multiple broadband technologies (e.g., mobile wireless, fixed wireless, satellite, fiber, cable, and DSL) compete at scale, as no one network is perfect for every use or user. There is a high degree of symbiosis and convergence between technologies and platforms. Consumers enjoy a variety of business models to connect to the internet, particularly free and reduced-cost options sponsored by third parties or the ISPs themselves.

Under internet freedom, consumers and innovators enjoy a common set of protections and competition standards delivered by the FTC. Limiting the FCC's role to make internet policy is important because sector-specific agencies are highly subject to capture by parties wanting to secure advantages by regulating their competitors. (104)

Internet regulation, or net neutrality, is a policy equating all data, regardless of the value to the user. Under net neutrality, the telecom regulator sets broadband's price, speed, and technology with the goal being a national, government-owned broadband monopoly.

Net neutrality advocates claim that ISPs require special rules to stop them from blocking or throttling Silicon Valley innovation. But there are few examples of actual harm to justify such prescriptive rules, and antitrust laws are already sufficient to punish, if not preclude, such behavior. Indeed, ISPs' very business models are based on building the networks for Americans to access the products and services of Silicon Valley, and Silicon Valley takes the lion's share of the connected industry's stock performance, revenue, profitability, and growth. (105) The New York Times reports that the real threat to Silicon Valley is not the nation's 4,551 ISPs, but Chinese internet giants, including Alibaba and Tencent, which make the US players look tame by comparison. (106)

Net neutrality is an amorphous but powerful concept that the FCC has used to enact rules, even though the FCC does not have the statutory authority to regulate the internet. During the Obama years, the FCC saddled the Comcast-NBCUniversal and Charter-Time Warner Cable mergers with net neutrality obligations for price and data trafic controls, programming requirements, and donations to certain congressional districts, requirements that would not have been palatable had they been presented in Congress. By placing these provisions within a consent decree, the FCC circumvented democratic processes and immunized the rulings from judicial review but achieved the Democratic Party's goals. (107) Understandably, the malleable net neutrality concept is important to Democratic Party politics, not only to realize the goals in the party platform but also to lay the groundwork for new regulations on platform regulation, hate

speech, and fake news. (108)

Research on the impact of net neutrality on innovation in mobile applications shows that no country with hard regulations for net neutrality has experienced increased innovation because of the rules. Countries with soft rules, such as codes of conducts, self-regulation, and multi-stakeholder governance, experienced greater mobile app development and app ranking than did countries with hard rules, such as ex ante regulation or legislation. (109)

The 2015 Open Internet Order is instructive as a natural experiment to examine whether the FCC's stated goals were achieved--notably, increased investment and innovation. During the two years of the Open Internet Order and the preceding two to three years in which the FCC indicated its plans to regulate networks, there was less consumer sovereignty, innovation, and investment. (110) Comparing two years before and two years after the Open Internet Order, the FCC itself reports that new wireline broadband deployments declined by 55 percent, and wireless broadband deployments declined by 83 percent. (111) A counterfactual analysis suggests that the marketplace suffered an opportunity cost of $30-$40 billion annually because the FCC precluded two-sided market development. (112)

US Telecom offers numerous reports and analysis on broadband infrastructure investment and demonstrates a correlative effect with the imposition and repeal of the internet regulation. Broadband infrastructure investment peaked at $73.6 billion in 2014, fell to $73 billion in 2015, and then plummeted $2.4 billion to $70.6 billion in 2016. In 2017, it is estimated to have rebounded by $2-$4 billion in expectation of the repeal of the onerous rules. (113)

Chairman Pai testified to Congress in August 2017 that the FCC's internet regulation was followed by two years of successive decline in broadband infrastructure investment, the first time such a downturn has been reported in a non-recessionary period. He shared an unsolicited letter from VTel, a small ISP in Springfield, Vermont, noting, "Regulating broadband like legacy telephone service would not create any incentives for VTel to invest in its broadband network. In fact, it would have precisely the opposite effect." Since the removal of the harmful regulation, VTel has "committed $4 million to purchase equipment and services from Ericsson to upgrade its LTE core to enable voice roaming and Wi-Fi calling to all our Vermont rural subscribers and to simultaneously begin rolling out faster mobile broadband that will start our transition to 5G." VTel concluded that it "is quite optimistic about the future, and the current FCC is a significant reason for our optimism." (114)

The FCC reversed the Open Internet Order in December 2017 upon finding that it harmed consumers, innovators, and investment. In its place, the FCC voted for the Restoring Internet Freedom Order. (115) A chorus of tech media described the Restoring Internet Freedom Order as "the end of the internet" and "gutting all internet protections." (116) In fact, the order strengthens the transparency rules on internet access, restores the FTC's jurisdiction to police harm on broadband subscriptions, and returns to the policy that made the US preeminent in the internet. In addition, the FTC and FCC now share jurisdiction on broadband, offering two cops on the beat, not one. (117)

Nevertheless, congressional Democrats are using the Congressional Review Act (CRA) to attempt to reimpose the 2015 Open Internet Order. The Senate passed the CRA 52-47, with 47 Democrats, two independents, and Sens. Susan Collins (R-ME), John Kennedy (R-LA), and Lisa Murkowski (R-AK) in support. An effort in the House has 177 Democrat supporters and needs 218 for a simple majority, but it is unlikely to go forward at this point. (118)

The use of the CRA has had a resurgence in the current administration, and congressional Republicans have passed a record 16 resolutions disapproving of regulatory agencies' overreach in the prior administration. (119) The net neutrality CRA is the first time Democrats have wielded the legislation and the first time it has been attempted to restore regulations that had been removed, an action that violates the spirit of the CRA's purpose.

Passing a CRA is by no means easy. (120) While the net neutrality CRA passed in the Senate, where the Republican majority is thin, it faces an uphill battle in the House. Moreover, the president has vowed to veto the item if it comes to his desk. (121)

Even if the net neutrality CRA passed these hurdles, there would likely be litigation. The explicit CRA statute applies only to agency rules, but the net neutrality CRA attempts to restore an order. (122) Rules and orders are not legally the same. There is also a procedural issue of whether the 2015 FCC duly informed Congress of the Open Internet Order, which could potentially make the entire order moot for CRA purposes. Ongoing legal challenges against the 2015 order, including seven petitions at the Supreme Court, could also terminate the policy. (123)

Various polls are promoted by the tech press and policymakers as evidence of overwhelming public support for internet regulation. (124) While these polls are indicative of sentiment from some respondents, they fail to give an accurate picture of the diverging views of Americans overall, including a large number who have never heard of the term "net neutrality." The polls suffer from statistical bias with loaded questions and definitions that lead to a preferred response. (125) When asked open-ended questions, such as how to define net neutrality and how to regulate it, a leading poll suggests that as many as 75 percent of Americans have not heard of the topic or cannot explain it. (126) The attempt to define net neutrality in a way that all can understand remains elusive, as activists demonstrated with a political Burger King commercial that drew mixed response. (127)

While there may be general support among Americans to protect the internet (but not necessarily to regulate it with price controls) and specific support for net neutrality among millennials, there is not necessarily an agreed definition or preferred policy instrument. Indeed, some espouse neutrality as a standard of nondiscrimination that should be applied across the entire internet ecosystem, not just to ISPs. (128)

Democrats advocate for the arcane administrative designation of Title II of the 1934 Communications Act to be applied to broadband, which empowers the FCC to regulate the internet with the same tools used for the telephone monopoly. But there are viable alternatives to Title II. (129)

Importantly, the term "net neutrality" does not appear in the FCC's 2015 Open Internet Order or in any US statute. If the goal is to create net neutrality rules, Congress needs to make a specific law (or update the Communications Act) to spell out the term, what it means, and the regulator's role to enforce it. As such, advocates' calls to restore the FCC's 2015 rules will not create "net neutrality," let alone a lasting policy. Only Congress can make such rules. Notably, of the more than 50 countries with net neutrality rules, almost all have been made with new legislation, except for soft rule regimes in Japan and South Korea, ongoing for more than a decade, and the successful voluntary code of conduct in Switzerland. (130)

The Role of Policy in Elections

The previous sections discussed political parties writ large and the substance of tech policy. An equally important, however complex, question is how political parties' policies translate to voters. Political scientists have modeled the role of policy in elections, finding that candidates' positions systematically influence voters' decisions (131) and that voters use elections to decide which of two opposing views will be implemented. (132)

While public policy plays a role in elections, tech policy does not appear to be a key driver. A national Pew Research Center longitudinal poll of 1,500 adults over the past decade notes that leading concerns are the economy, terrorism, and education. (133) Notably, the economy, jobs, and the budget deficit, while still ranking high as public policy priorities, have declined in importance over the past decade. The priorities that have risen most in importance are the environment, transportation, and drug addiction, but these concerns are still outweighed by health care and Social Security. No tech policy issue is listed as a priority.

Gallup charts the volatility of Americans noting economic issues as the most pressing problem facing the nation since 2000. It also provides the breakdown of what Americans believe are the most pressing economic and noneconomic problems. No tech policy issue, including the internet and the presence or lack of regulation, is mentioned among more than 40 enumerated problems. (134)

This is not an exhaustive review, but if tech policy played a pivotal role in elections, it should emerge, at least anecdotally, in two of the leading polls. It does not.

Democrats' Wedge Strategy on Net Neutrality to Win Millennials. Even though tech policy is not a top priority with voters, Democrats appear to be using net neutrality as a wedge issue for millennial voters. Wedge issues are controversial issues that political parties use to create a "wedge" within their opposition, exploit the natural instability within coalitions, and heighten polarization between the parties. (135) Wedge issues need not be an explicit part of the party platform but can exemplify party values and objectives. They must be sufficiently controversial to provide fodder for politically salient talking points and media coverage.

There is evidence that wedge issues can convince persuadable voters in swing states. (136) The Persuadable Voter: Wedge Issues in Presidential Campaigns suggests that wedge issues such as abortion, gay marriage, and immigration have emerged precisely because technology allows candidates to target voters who are responsive to "controversial" issues. (137)

Political scientist Elmer Schattschneider described the notion of a wedge or fringe position or extreme group becoming mainstream: "Political conflicts are waged by coalitions of inferior interests held together by a dominant interest. The effort in all political struggles is to exploit cracks in the opposition while attempting to consolidate one's own side." (138) This could explain in part how policymakers have succeeded in gathering attention with divisive communication on net neutrality and online privacy. (For example, "Big corporations are trying to break the internet and destroy your privacy. Only our government intervention can protect you.") The other topics of tech policy are dry and less susceptible to emotional appeal.

In May 2018, the New York Times described net neutrality as the "centerpiece" of Democrats' midterm strategy and "part of a three-legged stool--internet access, gun control and marijuana legalization--they are leaning on to entice young voters to engage in the midterm elections." (139) At a press conference for Operation #OneMoreVote on February 27, 2018, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer declared, "If our Republican friends don't wise up and join us, Democrats will be making net neutrality a major issue in the 2018 elections, and we will win." (140)

Six months earlier, Wired magazine explained, "Democrats and advocacy groups are already using internet-policy decisions as political weapons against Republicans." (141) The article detailed how Republicans who disapproved of the 2015 FCC's controversial internet and online privacy regulation were excoriated with inflammatory Google search ads and billboards in their districts decrying their voting record and campaign contributions.

In addition to marking Republicans as opponents of regulation purported to "save the internet," Axios describes how Democrats are using the issue to galvanize a small but committed group of midterm voters. (142) "Here's the thing: I'm not suggesting that this is going to move the majority of voters. What I'm telling you is that for millions of motivated and infrequent voters, this is a top issue," says Sen. Brian Schatz (D-HI). (143) Noting its relevance for young voters, Sen. Claire McCaskill (D-MO) commented, "I'm not sure how many Missourians are as tuned in to net neutrality. Especially once you get over the age of about 35 or 40, I'm not sure people are as aware about what the problems are." (144) However, Sen. Cory Gardner (R-CO), who leads the Republican Senate campaign arm, said that if "the Democrats want to run on regulating the internet, I think that's a losing strategy." (145)

It remains to be seen whether Democrats' strategy to motivate millennials to vote in the November election will succeed. But nonetheless, they are smart to recognize that millennials are an important constituency, given their size as a demographic block. By 2020, millennials will outnumber the baby-boomer generation. Moreover, they overwhelmingly identify as Democrat. (146)

Millennials were decisive in the 2008 and 2012 presidential elections, (147) but they have historically low turnout in midterms. Only half reliably vote. If millennials double their national turnout in the 2018 midterm and vote Democrat, this could result in an additional four million votes, which could be pivotal in many districts. (148) However, some see this as overly optimistic. (149)

The GOP does not appear to have a midterm strategy for millennials, preferring what the Atlantic describes as "doubling down on its older white base--and hoping the more diverse Millennials don't show up to the polls." (150) Republican pollster Kristin Soltis Anderson observes that "conservatives have done little to bridge the generation gap, or even effectively to make their case, instead treating young people as at best a nuisance and at worst a problem." (151) She advises that the GOP should emphasize free markets, families and communities as the cure for loneliness, tax cuts, and limited government as essential for entrepreneurship.

Conservative commentator Ben Shapiro observes, "The problem isn't politics. It's values." (152) He suggests that if Republicans want to connect with millennials, they must act and argue "morally." For Republicans to be relevant to millennials, they need to emphasize the human and emotional side of tech policy issues, such as how internet regulation is a tool of intolerance and government censorship and how government has snufed out innovation and entrepreneurship with heavy-handed regulation. Indeed, the appeal of internet regulation for millennials, who are "born digital," is being sentimental about the internet and identifying with the notion of needing to "save" and "protect" it. Older Americans, whose life precedes the internet, likely see the internet in utilitarian, not emotional, terms. By contrast, a free-market view suggests that the internet should be allowed to change, evolve, and improve, not frozen in time with government regulation.

Net Neutrality as Symbolic Politics. The debate surrounding net neutrality exemplifes "symbolic politics." This means that the ideas behind the policy proposals and the audiences to which they are directed matter more than whether the policies are adopted. (153) Key components of symbolic politics include communication as a form of political theater, milestones for the media narrative, and support from well-funded, professional advocacy organizations. These campaigns emphasize drama over analysis with simplistic, good-versus-evil narratives and a binary, all-or-nothing framing of the issues. (154)

Net neutrality campaigns such as Battle for the Net use inflammatory memes and Star Wars-like imagery to fetishize regulation. (155) These communications are undergirded by a sophisticated set of digital tools to manage and measure marketing efforts. For example, Battle for the Net's platform for CRA advocacy to Congress has been used to generate more than 17 million emails, 1.7 million phone calls, 500,000 text messages, and some 8,000 individual websites. (156)

The net neutrality CRA has been bolstered by events and efforts to pressure representatives to vote in favor of the resolution, including the One More Vote campaign on February 27 (specifically to pressure Republican senators), (157) a Day of Action to lobby Congress, (158) and calls to overwhelm the FCC with comments to its net neutrality regulatory proceeding. (159) These efforts are funded lavishly by major foundations and corporations. (160) They are a classic example of astroturfing, the practice of masking a sponsor's message with the appearance of grassroots support. (161)

In February 2018, nearly $1 million was spent per day to push House members to vote for the net neutrality CRA. According to one journalist, "This includes $168,000 per day in banner ads and $687,500 per day in 'Guaranteed Letter Signers' for 125,000 letters per day at $5.50 per letter. Between Feb. 2 and

Feb. 11, every U.S. House office was sent approximately 2,240 letters." (162)

Timed for the midterms, the worst fires in California's history were exploited with symbolic politics, turning a customer service mistake into a media frenzy. When firefighters experienced reduced cellular speeds on a single modem in a firetruck (among hundreds of modems deployed to fight the fire), net neutrality advocates pounced on the incident to claim that the provider was deliberating throttling the connection because there were no FCC rules to check its behavior, even though the 2015 rules allowed the traffic management practice. (163)

In response to this incident, the Santa Clara County fire chief was enjoined to file a brief in a suit against the FCC for its 2017 Restoring Internet Freedom Order filed by 23 state attorneys general, the California Public Utility Commission, California's Santa Clara County, and the Santa Clara County Fire District. The suit appears to be premeditated to claim that the FCC did not consider how the repeal would affect the subscriptions for public safety providers, even though the 2015 FCC rules applied to only mass market retail services for consumers, not subscriptions purchased by government and first responders. The petition even asserts, "Government Petitioners do not contend that this throttling would have violated the 2015 Order." (164) Indeed, public safety communications networks and subscriptions are predicated on prioritization and service-level agreements, the antithesis of the idea of a neutral network that treats all data equally.

That petitioners now impugn the FCC's statutory commitment to public safety suggests that the arguments in favor of the regulation are weak. The internet did not end when the rules were repealed, as regulatory proponents warned. Claims that public safety is now at risk is typical fodder for symbolic politics.

Fight for the Future's online mailing "First Responders for Net Neutrality" shamelessly declares, "But since the Federal Communications Commission repealed net neutrality rules and other key protections in December 2017, the communication services we rely on to do our jobs are no longer meaningfully protected from being arbitrarily slowed, blocked, or otherwise degraded by Internet service providers." (165) The mailing calls on respondents to tell their representatives to vote in support of the House CRA.

Along these lines, net neutrality activists unleashed a campaign to block the confirmation of Judge Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court. (166) When the DC Circuit voted to uphold the FCC's 2015 internet regulation, Judge Kavanaugh authored the dissent, noting that the rules violate the First Amendment and constitute a "major question," which requires Congress to be explicit about its intent. (167) The case has been appealed to the Supreme Court. (168)

Symbolic politics also serves an important function for political fundraising. Each net neutrality petition comes with a donation request. Nearly every member of Congress has benefited. Of the 535 members of Congress, 495 (or 93 percent) have received campaign contributions from groups that lobbied the FCC on net neutrality. Those members include 265 Republicans, 228 Democrats, and two independents--Sens. Bernie Sanders of Vermont and Angus King of Maine. (169)

State-level political actors have amplified symbolic politics by attempting to use various policy instruments to reinstate the FCC's 2015 rules, whether by governor's executive order, state legislation, or lawsuits by state attorneys general. (170) On the same day that California signed a net neutrality bill that goes even beyond the FCC's 2015 rules, the Department of Justice sued to block its implementation, noting that California's law is preempted by the FCC's deregulatory policy. (171) It is illegal for a state to regulate the internet and defy the FCC's preemption authority, but state actors persist nonetheless because of the political value they earn by purporting to "protect the internet." Such tactics, the conspicuous display of moral superiority, are also described as virtue signaling, "publicly displayed deception or surrogate action that is used to detract from actual political reality... a surrogate for politics." (172)

Even the Washington Post Editorial Board, which generally leans left, said that the California effort is a step too far and called on Congress to resolve the issue once and for all. (173) Since January 2017, the state of California has filed a record 44 lawsuits against the presidential administration, and three have been filed by the government against the state. The Sacramento Bee reports that the cost to taxpayers to date is more than $9 million for the 2017-18 fiscal year, up $3 million from the prior year. (1) (74)

Because of the global nature of the internet, Congress deemed that there needs to be a single national policy to govern it, which it states explicitly in the 1996 Telecommunications Act. It is neither practical nor tenable to require a person to obtain a new driver's license to drive in a new state or a new high school diploma to work in another state. Similarly, state-level internet regulation frustrates the current seamless digital market in which consumers can enjoy online content and services, regardless of which state it originates from. Consumers will likely reject 50 different sets of state requirements to connect online.

In any case, creating state-level internet rules is also illegal because of the Constitution's dormant commerce and supremacy clauses, the Communications Act, and the FCC's preemption authority. (175) Just as it would have been illegal for a state to disobey the FCC's 2015 order while it was in effect, it is illegal for states to disobey the FCC's policy now.

Even if some states succeed in promulgating their own internet policies, the question is how long these policies will withstand legal challenge in state and federal litigation. States will likely be too overwhelmed to defend their internet policies when they are fighting legal battles on dozens of other issues.

The point of states making their own internet policy may not necessarily be to enforce such rules but to gain symbolic victories before an election. For practical purposes, most states do not necessarily want to enforce their rules, and most of their public utility commissions are not equipped or situated to do so.

Moreover, it may be technically impossible to enforce these rules. State regulators can only regulate commerce that takes place within the state's borders. Thus, the state regulator would have to certify that the internet service is intrastate, originating and terminating within its state. Regulators would have to look into the internet packet to see its origin and destination, an impossible feat without a major investment in expensive deep packet inspection technology. Not only would the vast majority of internet streams fail to meet intrastate requirements, but state residents would be subject to surveillance by their state regulators under the premise of keeping the internet "free and open."

This is not to say that states such as California would not try to enforce their own internet regulation. Indeed, the California Public Utility Commission is larger in head count and budget than the FCC, has its own advocacy arm, and likely desires to use the premise of the state law to add a net neutrality tax to Californians' broadband bills. (176)

How Voters Learn About Tech Policy. Just as the internet has disrupted traditional industries, it has also changed how Americans stay informed. While this report describes political parties' websites, platforms, and communication about tech policy issues, these are some of the least "helpful" sources of political information for voters, according to Pew.

The Pew survey describes the leading sources of political information, which vary by voter age. These include cable TV news, social media, local television, news websites and apps, and radio. For millennials, social media and news websites are the most helpful, and millennials, compared to other age groups, are more likely to get political information from late-night comedy shows and issue-specific groups and websites. (177)

In U.S. Media and Elections in Flux: Dynamics and Strategies, David Jones describes the shift in Americans' preferred sources of information, noting that

Americans get their election news "on demand" rather than "by appointment." One of the key implications is that voters gravitate to sources that already cater to their preexisting views. (178)

Confirmation bias suggests that people interpret information in a way that already supports their preexisting views. For example, the president's supporters could interpret negative media coverage as evidence of his policies' success. Alternatively, his detractors could view positive coverage of the president or his policies negatively because they perceive it as their preferred policies failing.

The conventional view may be that news outlets report objective information on which voters can make electoral decisions. However, a 2017 report of the major official news outlets notes that news coverage is dominated by reporting of "who's up and who's down," to the detriment of coverage of substantive policy issues. (179) This trend has been afoot for some time. Communication and Midterm Elections: Media, Message, and Mobilization, which explores the media and the 2014 midterm, concurs that there was less media coverage of policy issues in the 2014 midterm. (180)

A similar trend could be observed in tech policy media in that the coverage of the politics of the issues supersedes the coverage of the policy substance. Over the past year and a half, highly politicized stories about online privacy and net neutrality dominated news coverage, whereas academic and evidenced-based discussions on these topics were limited. Moreover, these two issues are discussed frequently to the exclusion of substantive tech policy issues such as scientific research, spectrum, and regulatory instrumentation. (181)

In fact, the FCC took 78 substantive actions on 28 distinct policy issues in 2017, but tech journalists largely ignored these accomplishments. (182) Jon Brodkin of Ars Technica justified his lack of response in a tweet: "I'm ignoring so many major FCC accomplishments ... most of them are eliminating stuff the previous guy did or continuing stuff the previous guy did, but pay no attention to the details." (183)

Tech Policy and Politics

Symbolic politics can be effective to frame debates. Robert Atkinson and Doug Brake argue that some net neutrality advocates conduct a broader debate as a series of individual, tactical skirmishes over hot-button issues because they know that if the debate were about the strategic choice--for example, market solutions versus government control--a majority would favor the former. (184) However, digitally driven tech policy campaigns should not be underestimated; they have succeeded in capturing regulatory agencies and forcing Congress to capitulate on controversial bills.

A larger issue is whether the net neutrality campaigns will win votes, not just solidarity. Democrats tried an electoral strategy with net neutrality in 2010, but all 95 Democratic candidates running in part on net neutrality platforms lost their races. (185)

For wedge issues to succeed, they likely need to be linked to specific ballot initiatives. Merely associating a set of ideas with a party is probably not enough to bring voters to midterm elections; the policy ideas need to affect things voters deeply care about.

Additionally, net neutrality campaigns must overcome technological advancements that continue to make internet access better, faster, and cheaper. The FCC has concluded that there is an increasingly competitive market for broadband today. Moreover, recent policy has increased broadband deployment in rural areas, fast-tracked the deployment of 5G mobile wireless networks nationwide, and increased the availability of spectrum--policies that enjoy bipartisan support and that will likely reflect well on Republicans in the fall of 2018.

From 1996 to 2015, the US benefited tremendously from centralizing internet policy at the FTC because there was a common competition standard for all providers and common expectations for online privacy. This also kept states from creating contradictory rules. To put it another way, the US gained preeminence in the internet industry because American policy allowed providers to view the 50 states as a single market, not 50 individual markets with their own rules.

Once networks were built, devices, apps, and services had the capability for a national market with a common language, currency, and light-touch regulatory policy. Such a dynamic was never possible in the EU with its 24 languages, 17 currencies, and fragmented regulatory approach. (186) Despite its efforts to make a single digital market, the EU still lags on developing pan-European networks, services, and apps.

The beauty of the 1996 Telecommunications Act was that it said little about the internet other than that it should be free and unfettered from federal and state regulation. The act unleashed a torrent of innovation and investment that allowed the US to become the world's internet leader. However, this simple and straightforward language does not deter advocates from claiming that Congress gave the FCC authority to regulate the internet with the same instruments used for the Ma Bell telephone monopoly.

Centralizing internet policy at the FTC is a prudent, cost-effective regulatory solution. Most consumers intuitively understand what many policymakers do not: The internet is an interconnected, converged system that calls for the same rules across the board. This should be achieved by updating the FTC and

Communications Acts. Subsequently, sector-specific regulatory functions should be rationalized in favor of a general competition law. Unfortunately, entrenched interests want to exploit outdated statutes to realize preferred policy goals rather than regulatory reform that can legitimately help consumers.

Policy and regulation are not neutral; they benefit certain actors at the expense of others. Moreover, consumers and taxpayers are least likely to be represented by special interest groups. This is particularly the case with tech policy, which is sufficiently arcane to a general audience, making it even more susceptible to abuse by special interests. Although most Americans can benefit from good tech policy, its technical nature means it attracts interest from specialized scholars, advocates, and policymakers who prefer regulatory solutions because it gives them power they would not have otherwise. (187)

Making legislation now is imperative to end more than a decade of litigation on net neutrality, deter abuse of FCC authority, and end state-level policy fragmentation. Ideally, Congress will make modern rules to ensure that consumers and innovators enjoy common protections and competition standards across the ecosystem, enforced by the FTC. Apart from the divisive activist segment, there is room for bipartisan agreement on internet policy.

Conclusion

This report reviewed political parties' 2016 tech policy platforms, finding both commonalities and ideological differences but that the parties were consistent with their stated positions in the past two years.

Republicans achieved many tech policy goals described in their platform, especially advancing broadband infrastructure deployment and regulatory modernization. Democrats participated in bipartisan efforts such as agency reauthorization and online privacy and have defended internet regulation. Democrats have also made significant state-level internet policy, which contradicts the historical, federal, and bipartisan approach and will likely be struck down in court.

While some have claimed that net neutrality will be a defining wedge issue for the 2018 midterms and an effective means to activate millennials, there is little evidence that it will measurably affect votes, particularly with competition for other salient policy issues. The audience for tech policy is relatively small, though it is growing along with the tech economy.

While the substance of tech policy is important, its coverage in the media is largely limited to stories that describe the politics of a few hot-button issues. In the short run, net neutrality offers a compelling narrative for political communication, press coverage, and fundraising, but its role in elections is difficult to observe and measure. In the long run, however, internet freedom will lead to more economic growth and benefit more Americans.

About the Author

Roslyn Layton is a visiting scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, where she focuses on evidence-based policy for the information, communications, and digital technology industries.

urn:contentItem:5M94-HNX1-DYT4-V145-00000-00Tech reaches out to Donald Trump2016-11-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:35ZLexisNexisBUSINESSTech reaches out to Donald Trump

The tech industry has banded together in an attempt tocreach out to Donald Trump,cthe president-elect it tried to defeat.

Seventeen trade groups sent a letter to Trump Tuesday, asking him to consider principles the industry says will help growth and innovation. The groups pushed for government investment in tech infrastructure, tax reform and modernizing rules and laws.

They also felt the need to toot their own horn a little.

cWe are a powerful engine for economic growth and competitive strength, driving over $1 trillion into the American economy,c the groups wrote. cIndeed, we are increasingly the platform for powering everything from small main street businesses to the leading powerhouse companies that are the envy of the world.c

The groups, which include the Consumer Technology Association, TechNet and the Silicon Valley Leadership Group, count among their members companies such as Google, Facebook, Amazon and Twitter. One of the groups that signed this letter, the Internet Association, had already sent Trump a wish list cwith policy priorities a couple of weeks ago.

When asked whether Trump responded to the groupcs previous letter,cthe Internet Association would not comment. Instead, it provided this statement to SiliconBeat from CEO Michael Beckerman: cThe internet industry looks forward to working with the Trump administration on policies that will help grow jobs and opportunity for all Americans.c

SiliconBeat has asked the Trump transition team for comment but has not received a response.

The big joint letter comes amid some concerns about how Trump and his cabinet picks will affectcissues that are important to tech, such as net neutrality , government surveillance , immigration and more. Trumpcs tech policies remain largely a mystery.

Meanwhile, at least one of Trumpcs picks, Elaine Chao for transportation secretary, is getting a positive reaction from Uber and Lyft, Bloomberg reports. Chao, who served as labor secretary under President George W. cBush and deputy secretary of transportation under President George H.W. Bush, has publicly expressed support for the gig economy. It is unknown what Chaocs position is on another big tech issue she would face: self-driving cars , an emerging technology thatcs mired in regulatory challenges galore.

Photo: Donald Trump gives his presidential acceptance speech at the New York Hilton Midtown in the early morning hours of Nov. 9, 2016 in New York City. (Mark Wilson/Getty Images)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5NSP-G7M1-DYWP-R2TV-00000-00Tech recovery sends Wall St. to records with Fed next2017-06-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:30:35ZLexisNexisBUSINESSTech recovery sends Wall St. to records with Fed next

REUTERS: Wall Street gained on Tuesday, with the S&P 500, Dow industrials and Russell 2000 setting record closing highs, as technology stocks bounced back and investors positioned for an expected Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The S&P 500 technology sector rose 0.9 percent, recovering from its biggest two-day decline in nearly a year that also weighed on the broader market. Big tech names, such as Microsoft and Facebook , pushed the S&P 500 higher.

"I think the fall the last two days has been due to psychology not to any fundamentals, and today you re seeing some people step back in and buy again," said Peter Tuz, president of Chase Investment Counsel in Charlottesville, Virginia. "Fundamentals look good." Tech has led the benchmark S&P 500's 9-percent rally this year, and its recent swoon has sparked speculation that investors may be rotating into other swaths of the market that have lagged in 2017, such as financials and energy. Financials gained 0.4 percent on Tuesday, while energy gained 0.7 percent. Materials were the top gaining sector, rising 1.3 percent. Tuesday's market action reflected "a continuation of running up some of the areas that have not participated over the course of the last few months, in combination with some speculation that the Fed is going to be more resolute about raising rates than investors had begun to anticipate in the bond market," said Bruce McCain, chief investment strategist at Key Private Bank in Cleveland. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 92.8 points, or 0.44 percent, to 21,328.47, the S&P 500 gained 10.96 points, or 0.45 percent, to 2,440.35 and the Nasdaq Composite added 44.90 points, or 0.73 percent, to 6,220.37. Traders are overwhelmingly expecting an interest rate increase when the Fed concludes its two-day meeting on Wednesday. The central bank is scheduled to release its decision at 2 p.m EDT (1800 GMT) on Wednesday with a news conference to follow from Fed Chair Janet Yellen. Financials, which tend to benefit when rates are rising, also climbed after the U.S. Treasury Department announced a plan to upend the country's financial regulatory framework, which would grant many items on Wall Street's wishlist. In corporate news, Cheesecake Factory shares fell 9.9 percent after the restaurant chain warned of a decline in comparable store sales. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones on the NYSE by a 2.39-to-1 ratio; on Nasdaq, a 1.89-to-1 ratio favored advancers. About 6.4 billion shares changed hands in U.S. exchanges, below with the 6.8 billion daily average over the last 20 sessions. (Additional reporting by Sruthi Shankar and Yashaswini Swamynathan in Bengaluru; Editing by Anil D'Silva and Nick Zieminski) - Reuters
